@jamiedixon @babeljs you can also check the output, without minifying/uglify, to see what have been injected/imported by babel/webpack 🎉
@jamiedixon @babeljs README: "...One option is to create single entry file that only contains the require statement. (for babel-polyfill)"
@jamiedixon @babeljs I use it as the first vendor on my "vendors" file (I prefer to have a JS file instead of a webpack entry)
@jamiedixon @babeljs I guess not, on the README, they recommend to use the "require('babel-polyfill') (or import), once in the whole app...
@jamiedixon @babeljs useBuiltIns, will replace your "babel-polyfill" declaration/import by the-only-necessary polyfills based on your target
@jamiedixon @babeljs and here: https://t.co/r2jFwiirsM, also, there's a option to allow built-ins polyfills, here: https://t.co/6P9tAelQ7w
@jamiedixon @babeljs depends on the browsers you're targeting, you can check what will be included in: https://t.co/gZ8QmMpNDq (1/3)
